newborn/ 07074 / 6.0

table_items.text: Clarification to point 6.9; 8.0; Appendices A and E
Addition of the Neonatal Bleep for code Blue held by Senior Nurse at all times, also checking the baby's head for injury following an assisted vaginal birth( recommendations from Coroners Report)

data.text: Contents
Preparation before delivery..……………………………………….…………….
Resuscitation Pathway………..………………………………………………….
Management of Significant Meconium Stained Liquor (MSL) .................................... 11

Appendix C: Initiating an Emergency Code Blue ............................................................... 17 Appendix D: Labour Ward Neonatal Resuscitation Trolley Check list ................................ 18 Appendix E: Resuscitaire Equipment for the stand-alone birthing units ............................. 20 Appendix F: Preliminary Equality Analysis ......................................................................... 21
Introduction

Until such time that the newly born infant has successfully made the transition to air breathing, it is dependent on the placenta and umbilical cord for respiration. The normal function of both of these may be interrupted by a number of pathological events before or during the birth process (e.g. by placental abruption, cord entanglement, etc.) giving rise to a hypoxic insult that may be acute, chronic or both (acute on chronic). Although most infants cope with the process of birth well, the few that do not may require help to establish normal breathing at delivery. The majority of these infants merely require supported perinatal transition rather than ‘resuscitation'.

Resuscitation or support of transition is more likely to be needed by babies with intrapartum evidence of significant fetal compromise, babies delivering before 35 weeks gestation, babies delivering vaginally by the breech, maternal infection and multiple pregnancies. Furthermore, caesarean delivery is associated with an increased risk of problems with respiratory transition at birth requiring medical interventionsespecially for deliveries before 39 weeks gestation. However, elective caesarean delivery at term does not increase the risk of needing newborn resuscitation in the absence of other risk factors.
Scope
To Identify the at risk groups of babies who may require active resuscitation of the newborn.
By identifying at risk groups the equipment, staff and environment can be prepared for resuscitation.
To prepare midwives and medical staff for the resuscitation process by using the accepted algorithm.
(Refer to Appendix A)
Definitions

table_items.text: Birthing Unit at Braintree Community Hospital

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
Role and responsibilities within the Trust

4.1.1 Managing Director has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors.

4.1.2 Medical Director has strategic responsibility for ensuring systems are in place to promote awareness of this policy amongst medical staff and to provide support in adhering to practice as described.

4.1.3 Director of Nursing has strategic responsibility for ensuring systems are in place to facilitate the nursing staff's awareness of this policy and appropriate support is given to enable staff in delivering practice as outlined in this policy.
Role and responsibilities of individuals within the Trust

4.2.1 The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
4.2.2 The Clinical Director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.

4.2.3 The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers as well as the Head of Nursing and Quality for Children and Young People, Paediatric and Neonatal Managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.

4.2.4 The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant as well as the Lead Consultant for the Neonatal Unit are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within their clinical settings.

4.2.5 It is the overall responsibility of the senior midwives in all care settings to ensure that the resuscitation equipment used by the maternity service is checked, stocked and fit for purpose on a daily basis. In addition, it is the individual midwives' responsibility to ensure that resuscitation equipment within each care setting is fit for purpose on a daily basis
4.2.6 All staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
At risk groups
There are some babies that are more at risk of requiring Neonatal Resuscitation:
Prematurity in particular gestations of <33 weeks
The presence of significant MSL or oligohydramnios (Refer to the guideline for the ‘Management of meconium stained liquor'; register number 04259)
Asphyxia which may present as late decelerations or fetal bradycardia/tachycardia on the cardiotocograph (CTG) tracing; or in the presence of cord prolapse or placental abruption
Known fetal abnormality
Multiple births
Emergency /Code Blue
Code Blue is defined as an emergency situation involving a collapsed baby or baby born in poor condition that requires an urgent ‘crash call' response using the emergency call number
Specify code BLUE
Give location to switchboard (e.g. A4, Maternity – Labour Ward (Rmno.)/Postnatal Ward/DAU)
(Refer to Appendix B)
Resuscitation Equipment (Refer to Appendix C)
5.3.1 Resuscitation equipment should be available in all care settings as follows:
Labour Ward
Co-located Birthing Unit (Broomfield Hospital)
Postnatal Ward
Day Assessment Unit
Midwife-led Units (Braintree/Maldon)
Accident and Emergency (Broomfield Hospital)
Obstetric theatres 1 and 2 located on Labour Ward
Community Midwives

5.3.2 Labour Ward (to include the obstetric theatres) has 4 separate neonatal trolleys that are stocked with neonatal drugs and neonatal equipment for resuscitation and intubation. The 2 Labour Ward neonatal trolleys are located in the equipment room.

5.3.3 There is a Panda resuscitaire located in the triage room on Day Assessment Unit (DAU) and a separate neonatal trolley that is fully stocked with neonatal drugs and neonatal equipment for resuscitation and intubation in the clean utility room.

5.3.4 There is a Panda resuscitaire located on the Postnatal Ward; in the neonatal resuscitation room with a separate neonatal trolley that is fully stocked with neonatal drugs and neonatal equipment for resuscitation and intubation. The neonatal trolley is located in the drug preparation room.
5.3.5 The Panda resuscitaire and neonatal equipment should be checked on a daily basis and recorded and signed off on the neonatal record sheets provided.  .
5.3.6 All community midwives carry basic resuscitation equipment including:
Guedel airway;
Portable oxygen cylinder;
Penlon bag.
5.3.7 Community midwives should check their neonatal equipment daily and this should be recorded and signed off on the statistical sheets provided.

5.3.8 For WJC community midwives at St Michael's Hospital, Braintree and St. Peters community midwives at Maldon; the neonatal equipment is checked fit for purpose and stored in ‘pool cars'; the community midwife should check their neonatal equipment daily. This daily check should be recorded and signed off on the neonatal sheets provided.

5.3.9 For the Midwife-led Units: WJC at St Michael's Hospital, Braintree; and St Peters, Maldon the Panda resuscitaires and neonatal equipment should be checked on a daily basis recorded and signed off on the neonatal record sheets provided. (Refer to Appendix D).
5.3.10 Neonatal nursing staff attending code blue will bring supplementary equipment in ‘grab bag'.
Preparation before Delivery
5.4.1 Relevant staff with new born life support skills should be available to attend deliveries, this includes:
Paediatric Senior House Officer and Registrar (24 hour cover bleep holder);
Paediatric Consultant (24 hour cover availability contact via switchboard);

The senior neonatal nurse carries a bleep which is linked to the code blue. This will alert the Neonatal nurses of a code blue. If their presence is required Labour ward staff or the paediatricians will contact the Neonatal Unit for assistance.
5.4.2 Inform the teams below as well as:
Inform and update the Labour Ward Co-ordinator;
Inform the Neonatal Unit if an admission is anticipated.
5.4.3 Ensure the room is warm.
5.4.4 Prepare resuscitaire and switch the heater on. Check equipment making sure the size of masks, tubes etc. is appropriate for the gestation.
5.4.5 Have plastic bag available if below  weeks gestation.
5.4.6 Check drugs are available.
5.4.7 Explain to parents what is happening.
5.4.8 When entering the room introduce yourself to parents if appropriate.

5.4.9 For uncompromised term and preterm infants, a delay in cord clamping of at least one minute is recommended. However, for infants requiring resuscitation, resuscitative intervention remains the immediate priority.

5.4.10 During an assisted vaginal birth the use of forceps or other instruments has an increased risk of trauma to the infant, obstetricians should be aware of the increased risks and during resuscitation the obstetricians should inform the paediatricians that it was an instrumental assisted birth. The paediatrician should manage the baby appropriately including an examination of the baby's head prior to applying the hat for any injuries such as lacerations or potential skull fractures.
5.4.11 The attending paediatrician should seek a handover of information from the obstetric or midwifery staff about the situation using the SBAR communication tool.
Pathway
5.5.1 Start the clock.
5.5.2 For infants 31-40 weeks dry and cover while doing this assess the Apgar and examine the head before putting on a hat. Change wet towels immediately.

5.5.3 Infants 30 weeks gestation and below should be completely covered up to their necks in a food-grade plastic wrap or bag, without drying, immediately after birth. They should then be nursed under a radiant heater and stabilised. They should remain wrapped until their temperature has been checked after admission. For these infants the delivery room temperatures should be at least 26°C.

5.5.4 Thermoregulation of preterm babies delivered at home should be supported by wrapping in polythene and placed next to a warm object - such as mothers' skin – and covered with a warm towel. Consideration also needs to be given to increasing ambient temperature and eliminating draughts. They should be transported in a warm vehicle.

5.5.5 Assess colour, tone, breathing and heart rate and continue to reassess these observations every  seconds throughout resuscitation. The responsible practitioner should ensure that the neonate is assessed and the Apgar score is accurately calculated and documented in the Baby Delivery Record.
5.5.6 Call for help and a neonatal nurse now or at any time in the resuscitation process.
5.5.7 If the baby is not breathing open the airway by placing the head in the neutral position and reassess.
Resuscitation of the newborn/ 07074 / 6.0

5.5.8 If still not breathing give 5 inflation breaths using an appropriate sized mask and T piece or bag and appropriate sized mask if T piece not available. Each breath should last 2-3 seconds and exert 30cms/H20 (lower pressure should be given to preterm infants) and reassess if no increase in heart rate look for chest movement.

5.5.9 For term infants, air should be used for resuscitation at birth. If, despite effective ventilation, oxygenation (ideally guided by pulse oximetry) remains unacceptable, use of a higher concentration of oxygen should be considered.

5.5.10 Preterm babies less than 32 weeks gestation may not reach the same arterial blood oxygen saturations in air as those achieved by term babies. Therefore blended oxygen and air should be given judiciously and its use guided by pulse oximetry. If a blend of oxygen and air is not available use what is available.

5.5.11 If NO chest movement recheck head position, apply jaw thrust and repeat inflation breaths. Reassess if no increase in heart rate repeat sequence as in point 8.8. Consider using an oropharyngeal airway or 2 person jaw thrust. Is the airway clear
- consider suction.
5.5.12 When chest is moving and heart rate is satisfactory give ventilation breaths at a rate of approximately  per minute until the baby is breathing adequately.

5.5.13 If heart rate is below  bpm with adequate chest movement give 1 round of ventilation breaths and reassess prior starting cardiac compressions, if there remains no improvement in heart rate start chest compressions at 3 compressions to one ventilation breath, at a rate to give 120 events per minute. Position hands as to grip the chest with the thumbs positioned on the sternum at the level of an imaginary line drawn between the nipples and the fingers under the back, Compress the chest quickly by about one third. Reassess every  seconds.
5.5.14 If the heart rate increases stop compressions and continue ventilation breaths until the baby is breathing adequately.

5.5.15 If there is no response with effective ventilation and cardiac compressions, resuscitation drugs should be administered. Intravenous access should be obtained using the umbilical vein for central administration.
5.5.16 Newly born infants born at term or near term with evolving moderate to severe hypoxic – ischaemic encephalopathy should, where possible, be treated with therapeutic hypothermia.
5.5.17 After all resuscitations all actions, procedures and drugs must be fully documented in the maternal notes.
Drugs
Epinephrine (Adrenaline) 1:10,000
Dose:
If given then the intravenous route is recommended using a dose of 0.1ml - 0.3 ml/kg (10-30 mcg kg)
If the tracheal route is used, it is likely that a dose of at least 0.5ml – 1ml/kg (50- 100 mcg kg) will be needed to achieve a similar effect to 10 mcg/kg intravenously
Sodium Bicarbonate 4.2% (8.4% can be diluted ml to 1:1 with normal saline 0.9%)
Dose 1-2 mmols/kg (2 – 4 mls/kg of 4.2 %)
If there is no response to epinephrine, giving sodium bicarbonate prior to the nd dose may help as the epinephrine action is reduced if acidaemia is present
Dextrose 10% 250mg/kg (2.5ml/kg).
Management of Significant Meconium Stained Liquor (MSL)
(Refer to the guideline for the ‘Management of meconium stained liquor'; register number 04259)
If significant MSL is present and the baby is crying and breathing well do not suction.

If presented with a floppy, apnoeic baby born through significant MSL it is reasonable to inspect the pharynx rapidly to remove potential obstructions. If appropriate expertise is available, tracheal intubation and suction may be useful. However, if there is no-one present with the correct expertise or if attempted intubation is prolonged or unsuccessful, start mask ventilation, particularly if there is persistent bradycardia.
Cord bloods
Cord blood gases should be taken routinely where a baby has a poor apgar assessment at delivery.

(‘Management of Normal Labour and Prolonged Labour in Low risk Patients'; register number 09079; and 09113 Guidelines for ‘Calling Paediatric Staff and Obtaining Paediatric Referral'; register number 09113)
Training requirements

All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training, to include attending a course in neonatal resuscitation.  (Refer to ‘Mandatory training policy for Maternity Services (incorporating training needs analysis. Register number 09062)
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Midwifery staff undertaking neonatal resuscitation should have annual updates and in house training or should attend the Neonatal Life Support course.
Paediatricians and neonatal staff should attend the Neonatal Life Support course four yearly
Guideline Management

9.5.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Infection prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.

All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using High Impact Intervention guidelines to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Professional midwifery advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practicing midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Monitoring and audit

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

Documentation should describe the process for ensuring that all appropriate maternal screening tests are offered, undertaken and reported on during the antenatal period, which as a minimum must include a description of the:
Identification of a designated link paediatrician for the Labour Ward and Neonatal Service, responsible for the clinical standards in relation to the care of the newborn;
Process for documenting that the resuscitation equipment used by the Maternity Service is checked, stocked and thereby fit for use in all care settings ;
Deliveries to be attended by a clinician (doctors, advanced neonatal nurse practitioner, midwives) with newborn life support skills;
Process for the availability of a clinician with newborn life support skills at a delivery if required;

Process for 24 hour availability in obstetric units (on site within 30 minutes), of a consultant paediatrician (or equivalent staff and associate specialist grade) trained and assessed as competent in newborn life support skills;
Maternity service's expectations in relation to staff training, including newborn life support skills, as identified in the training needs analysis;
Process for monitoring compliance with all of the above requirements, review of results and subsequent monitoring of action plans.

A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum  requirements as highlighted in point 14.2 will be audited. A minimum compliance  75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance
Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynecology Practice Steering Group and Paediatric Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynecology Practice Steering Group, Paediatric Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix F)
References
Resuscitation Council UK, 2016. Newborn life support – resuscitation at birth. th  ed.London:Resuscitation Council UK., London.
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, 2014. Intrapartum care for
healthy women and babies (CG190).London:NICE. Available at: www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg190
Ch8 “Resuscitation of the newborn baby” by Penny Champion IN Davies L and McDonald S, 2008. Examination of the newborn and neonatal health: a multidimensional approach. London:Churchill Livingstone.
RCOG, 2020. Assisted vaginal birth (Green-top Guideline 26). London:RCOG.Available at: www.rcog.org.uk/en/guidelines-research- services/guidelines/gtg26/

Appendix C: Initiating an emergency Code Blue
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust Women's, Children's and Sexual Health Directorate
There are two types of emergencies (code RED and code BLUE) that require urgent ‘crash call' responses using the new  emergency call number.
Initiating an emergency
Co-ordinator/senior staff member to initiate code
Dial
Specify code RED or code BLUE (see below criteria)
Give location to switchboard (e.g. A4, Maternity – Delivery Suite or Postnatal Ward)
Code RED for obstetric emergencies
Grade 1 caesarean section
Major/ massive haemorrhage
Maternal fitting
Cord prolapse
Code RED switchboard will fast bleep the following:
Labour ward co-ordinator (#6555 2017)
On call obstetric registrar
On call obstetric SHO
On call anaesthetist
On call anaesthetic assistant
On call paediatric registrar
On call paediatric SHO
Theatre scrub team
Code BLUE for collapsed baby
Code BLUE switchboard will fast bleep the following:
Labour ward co-ordinator (#6555 2017)
On call paediatric registrar
On call paediatric SHO
Resus officer (will only attend if available)
Neonatal Nurse ( will attend if requested by the paediatricians)
****** In the event of a maternal cardiac arrest you will still need to dial 2222******
Amended: October 2020

Neonatal thermometer
BM machine

Neonatal BVM
